This dude wants to break up, no doubt about it. Save yourself the time and complication and just end it. 

Once you two are living apart, you won‚Äôt ever live together again. It doesn‚Äôt make sense at this point to do something so drastic. Definitely other measures and boundaries can be taken to encourage independence. 

And on the flip side, why would you want to stay with someone who doesn‚Äôt want to live with you? Just mull that over in your head. How could you have a whole, integrated life with someone who doesn‚Äôt want to live together? How can the relationship even move forward logically if that‚Äôs the case? 

You two live apart for ??? say a few months. Things are good and then you move back in. Then it‚Äôs hard again. You want to be one of those couples that never lives together but is married? Sure, go this route. 

But it sounds to me like he wants to break up and is too scared to commit to it. Instead he asks you for space and living apar so he can essentially be single whenever you aren‚Äôt there. 

Nah girl. You deserve better.

Your Mom is right. This is not because you drunkenly called and vented to her about your struggle... it‚Äôs because your struggle involves violence, and the man (who supposedly loves you) choking you. 

He could kill you, dude. Neither of you sound stable, tbh, and if at this early on, you two are provoking each other into violence, then it will escalate given enough time and stress. 

You‚Äôve moved to an incredibly isolated area and I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised at all if this follows the typical abusive narrative. 

It‚Äôs shitty that his friend died, and shitty that you didn‚Äôt have the words to support him in that, but it will 100% never get better. Just worse, from this point forward. 

I doubt you‚Äôll leave. But hopefully you will come to your senses. And if not, you‚Äôll remember that your Mother fought for you in the early days.

Herpes is lifelong. Once you got it, it‚Äôs forever. The symptoms (outbreaks) may decrease over time and become more manageable, but it *never* goes away. 

Herpes can transmit it to anybody via viral shedding, whether there‚Äôs an active outbreak or not. So if you have it, you can and will give it eventually.  There is medication (antivirals) to reduce outbreaks and reduce transmission risk, but it‚Äôs always there. 

Many people have asymptomatic herpes, which means they just carry the virus but don‚Äôt ever express it (outbreak). They just give it to whoever, never knowing what they‚Äôre doing. 

Don‚Äôt determine your status by the status of your partner. You could have it and just gotten lucky to not transmit it yet. You could have it and given it to her and both be by asymptomatic. 

It could be a prank, but just go get tested. Herpes shows up in the blood by IGG and IGM measures. Research more on this, but it‚Äôs totally possible to find out if you have it without experiencing an outbreak. 

Herpes can kill infants, especially passing thru the birth canal, so if you ever wanna have kids with your fianc√©, find out now how risky that can be (natural childbirth during an outbreak). Just find out if you have it, that‚Äôs the first step. 

Essentially it‚Äôs just a lifelong ability to have painful rashes. There‚Äôs a huge stigma but it‚Äôs extremely common.

So sorry this happened to you. I would tell your partner. If he‚Äôs the kind of guy you believe him to be, then he‚Äôll have your back. This isn‚Äôt your fault, you didn‚Äôt do anything. He will be angry but at the man who violated and betrayed you, not you.

There‚Äôs no trauma Olympics. To tack on to the other commenter, there is little t trauma and big T trauma. Both are, you guessed it, traumatic. Your pain is valid, even if by comparison it‚Äôs ‚Äúless than,‚Äù someone else‚Äôs. But truly, any compassionate person would recognize it isn‚Äôt better or worse, it *just is*

YTA. You know that.

YTA. To agree with everyone else here, you shouldn‚Äôt trivialize her problems because you‚Äôre not in her shoes and what may seem ‚Äúeasily fixed‚Äù from the outside, may not be the case if you were her. 

To answer a question that you keep asking in your replies, there is a way to handle this that could have gotten you the results you wanted and saved this other girl some pointed pain. 

And that is that it‚Äôs not about *her*. This is 100% about you and your inability to hold firm boundaries (and possibly also about your attachment style of being avoidant when it comes to emotions/vulnerability). 

For example, if she was constantly complaining about a guy, you could have said ‚Äúfriend, I understand that you are frustrated about your situation. I am trying to hold space for your emotions as much as I can. However, I‚Äôm finding myself feeling very emotionally drained by this topic and moving forward, I won‚Äôt be engaging in conversation about it. ‚Äù  Then you would just... not talk to her about it. She can be angry about that or upset or whatever, but you don‚Äôt bend on the boundary after that. If she can‚Äôt respect it and repeatedly tries to violate it, then you end the relationship. 

You can‚Äôt change anyone else‚Äôs behaviour but you can take responsibility for your own boundaries or lack thereof. 

I think there‚Äôs a lot of ways you could reflect on this situation. I agree with another commenter that the friendship has run its course and that‚Äôs okay. I believe it would be helpful for you to get into counselling to have some introspection about your inability to hold space for your friends, your lack of firm boundaries, and the trivializing of their problems. 

I think a lot of people struggle with (your side) of this, so I hope you understand I‚Äôm not trying to sound mean. I just think this is an opportunity for you to work on yourself in meaningful ways and by your replies, I think that is what you want to do.

Look up CoCSA. It isn‚Äôt clear whether that‚Äôs happening here, but it‚Äôs your duty as an *adult* to report back to both sets of parents the inappropriateness of what you saw. That‚Äôs a six year age gap, a knowing preteen molesting a younger child. It‚Äôs not two 6 year olds ‚Äúexploring.‚Äù

She should get into counselling one on one, or at the very least, get into a grief support group. 

It‚Äôs okay that she wants more support and it‚Äôs understandable that you can‚Äôt give her as much as she needs and you want to. But it‚Äôs not just a one solution problem, there are other alternatives. 

She‚Äôs right that she has 60 years and she will need a supportive circle in her life. It isn‚Äôt right that she thinks all of that support should come from her husband. That‚Äôs some internalized societal stuff she needs to unpack and work toward changing. 

Grief is an always changing way of being and it won‚Äôt ever go away. It‚Äôs just going to shift. 

Be the best and supportive husband you can be by insisting she get therapy and even setting it up on her behalf. Accompany her to support groups. Read books on grief together. Do more, I say, but don‚Äôt do it all.
You can cancel a session for any reason, but you‚Äôre doing yourself a disservice.

Yea, I understand that discomfort. But your mother is a person with feelings and insecurities  completely independent of you and how you view her, or whatever complex, societal or cultural biases you hold. It‚Äôs okay that you don‚Äôt understand why she‚Äôs doing what she does, but you should try to be supportive. 

In your case, that means getting on board with whatever modifications she wants to do because ‚ë† she‚Äôs an autonomous person, outside of being ‚ÄúMom‚Äù and ‚ë° you don‚Äôt have to *agree* to **accept**.

And if you can, try to reframe this as an opportunity for yourself to get to know her as a *person*. Get curious, ask questions, find out her beliefs about things and her experiences that make her feel these changes are something she needs. Etc etc. Put a little distance between you two and get to know her like you would a friend. You may be surprised who she is outside of the role your pigeonholing her into right now.

Real talk, get into therapy. You have some type of boys dysmorphia and you may be only so far into that road. But you need to turn back. Now. This is 100% not about your body and completely about your mind. Get help.

Most cuddly cats are cuddly from kittenhood. It may just not be the case for yours. That being said, I intentionally went looking for a second cat that was more cuddly than my first. She was 13 weeks when I got her and very into snuggling. She‚Äôs almost a year old now and sometimes she lays on my side or on top of my hand. That‚Äôs it. Lol. 

But cats don‚Äôt show affection by just snuggling. My cats are almost always where I am, my second cat is vocal and talks to me, and they both sleep with me at night. I take this to mean they do love me. My first cat can be picked up and held like a baby. My second cat absolutely freaks if you hold her for more than .3 seconds. Lolol. 

Cats are individuals and unless you specifically search out a breed that prioritizes affection, then it‚Äôs just the luck of the draw when it comes to tabby‚Äôs.

Ugh. I have been there, as a woman. It can be very frustrating. Sex is a vulnerable activity and that ‚Äúletting go‚Äù in order to orgasm can be hard sometimes. 

Obviously you two have spoken about this and it makes sense that you *want* her to cum. And she obviously wants to, too. But I can see how she would feel some type of pressure, both from herself and from you. (Not saying you‚Äôre pushy or whatever)

It might be helpful to reframe sex. Ask her what she enjoys most about it beyond orgasming and what you can do to make a sexual encounter pleasurable without the orgasm. For me personally, I don‚Äôt need to orgasm every time. Would it be awesome to do so? Absolutely. Is it necessary? No. There‚Äôs a lot of pleasure (for me) in PIV from certain angles and the intimacy in general. With the right person, it doesn‚Äôt matter if I cum or not. Not to me, anyways. 

And I think if you work with her to shift the conversation from ‚Äúhow can we get you to orgasm every time‚Äù to ‚Äúhow can we work to get you to enjoy the sex, whether or not you orgasm‚Äù may be a good idea. It can be freeing, in a sense. 

People often see sex as a goal oriented activity with orgasm being what you‚Äôre working to get. But that doesn‚Äôt need to be the case, by any means. And it‚Äôs no reflection on either of you if orgasm isn‚Äôt the be all end all every time. 

Also introducing other standalone sex, like just oral for her for example, could be helpful. 

I don‚Äôt think this is worthy of breaking up, unless one or both of you is not willing to work with the other and be open enough in the ways that need be. Or the sex itself is just unfulfilling. 

It‚Äôs also worth saying that it could be unrelated to you. Most times I‚Äôve cried during sex or couldn‚Äôt cum,  it‚Äôs more to do with personal stress or relationship-focused stress than the specific stress of *not* being able to cum. I say that because I know (like ur gf probably knows) how to get myself off very quickly. It‚Äôs when my mind is clouded due to other reasons that I struggle. And I don‚Äôt want to speak for her, but I wonder if it‚Äôs similar for her.

That‚Äôs bullshit - there are tons of men that won‚Äôt scream and threaten you when they are angry. He‚Äôs young, he may think that‚Äôs just how he is, but he has the ability to change that. whether he wants to or not is another story. 

Besides the fact that being screamed at and belittled and threatened will definitely destroy the relationship given enough time, if he is physical when he‚Äôs angry, tht will also likely escalate in time. No, you sound very calm. You just don‚Äôt sound very in touch with your emotions. And like you‚Äôre in complete denial that you even have them. Which could mean your dissociating in those moments. 

Just sounds like a big disconnect that you need to bridge. And you do that by reflection and therapy. 

Also, there‚Äôs no easy answer. The best advice I can give is to disengage when the conflict arises to a point where there‚Äôs a clear miscommunication that isn‚Äôt getting resolved. Step away and calm down and have a convo when your not in an aroused emotional state.

It sounds like you‚Äôre stuck in that middle space of knowing what you meant but being betrayed by your tone, which puts your inner feelings (of defensiveness, hurt, shock, etc) on display. 

The best tone is an unaroused tone. Meaning, you don‚Äôt engage when you‚Äôre heated. You have to learn to respectfully step away from a conversation when you‚Äôre triggered and learn to ground yourself when you step away. 


That takes time and practice. I would encourage you to start seeing a therapist to help you deconstruct your triggers, practice speaking without a tone, having firm and reinforced boundaries, and how to disengage from a tense and conflicted moment. 

Ultimately, the issue isn‚Äôt people ‚Äúmisunderstanding‚Äù you - it‚Äôs that you have little control over your automatic reactions. When you (or anyone, really) get triggered, you instantly move into fight, flight, or freeze. And it takes a lot of conscious awareness to stay present and work through that; that‚Äôs why a therapist will help. 

It‚Äôs not an easy solution and it‚Äôs not something anyone else can or will do for you. You have to learn to be less.. reactive. And more responsive. That was the balancing act I found that most helped me. And I couldn‚Äôt have done that without a lot of introspection and therapy guided reflection.

Edit: also, if you hurt someone with your tone and they feel a certain way, you should apologize. If you find people are talking in circles with you over what you‚Äôve said to them, it‚Äôs because they take issue with it or how it was said. And it‚Äôs on you, as a reasonable and accountable adult, to consider what and how you said it and apologize. 

Ex: Mom, you‚Äôre right. That did sound ungrateful of me. I didn‚Äôt mean to imply that you didn‚Äôt do the best you could with what you had at the time and I am thankful for everything you‚Äôve done for me. In the future I will work on my tone so that what I mean to say comes across properly. I meant that all of those people have access to a lot of support and resources that not everyone has.

Yeah I‚Äôm gonna co-sign on this. 

OP, If you were that young and miming oral sex, then you were likely mimicking something you were being forced to do at or before that age. That‚Äôs what I would think, based on your description.

There‚Äôs two parts to communicating: content and tone. The content of what you‚Äôre saying sounds fine to me, but what‚Äôs missing (and I‚Äôm going to guess is the problem) is *how* you‚Äôre saying it. 

On top of tone, there is a lot that body language says and communicates to others. I used to hear a lot that I was rude and appeared bored by people talking to me. It wasn‚Äôt until a while later that someone told me I rolled my eyes once when she was talking and I swore that I hadn‚Äôt, that I realized my face makes expressions automatically and *I don‚Äôt register them.* I didn‚Äôt remember rolling my eyes, but of course, if someone rolled their eyes at me, I‚Äôd consider them condescending as well. 

It has taken a lot of time and awareness but it has helped me tremendously to reign in my tone, facial, and body expressions. I think this is probably what you‚Äôre dealing with and I would encourage you to really observe yourself, without judgement, in conversation, even if you have to get creative to do so (record an interaction, for example). 

Once you can view what you‚Äôre saying and doing from an outsiders perspective then you‚Äôll be able to fix what‚Äôs happening. Also, if *you* are getting angry in a conversation because you feel attacked, justifiably or not, you will for sure sound defensive and possibly combative to others (and not meaning to). It‚Äôs part of that instant reaction. It‚Äôs practice to learn to temper that.

Al anon is specifically geared toward people with alcoholics in their life. And not everybody meets that. Also, al anon is not a substitute for therapy - so much so that it‚Äôs stated in their manifesto. No, the point is not to continue forever. The point is to learn coping mechanisms that are healthy and get to a point where you can employ them regularly on your own. 

Also, that‚Äôs literally a therapists job. To be somebody‚Äôs springboard. Lol. Yes, that‚Äôs part of what somebody would want in therapy.. an unbiased listening ear. 

It‚Äôs okay that you don‚Äôt understand it. You don‚Äôt seem mentally ill and the concept doesn‚Äôt make sense to you.  That‚Äôs great, you don‚Äôt need it. But don‚Äôt pass judgement, even passively, on people that do need it and may need it longer than a few sessions. 

It‚Äôs not as easy for most people. Sometimes it can take years of therapy to peel back layers and layers of shame and self loathing to get to the root of a problem. Sometimes a therapist is the only safe person a person has. 

Either way, yes eventually it will likely end. Unless there‚Äôs a disorder that needs more consistency. In that case, therapy sessions scale up or down. Sometimes you go once or twice a week for a while and then scale
back to once a month while you‚Äôre doing better. Then it can move it once every couple weeks while you need more support. It‚Äôs always shifting for most people.

Edit: if it helps, think of it like exercise. Your whole life you need to exercise (having a safe, supportive person to lean on), because it‚Äôs good for you. But how often you go and what you do depends on your goals. If you‚Äôre trying to lose weight, you go more often. If you‚Äôre in maintenance mode, you go less. If you are trying to gain muscle, you go either more or less but what you do during your session changes. Maybe that will help you get the gist of it.

The whole point of therapy is to create a safe environment with a safe person. And to practice having a safe and ethical relationship with someone. 

Counterintuitive seems like the wrong word.. mostly because the transference of emotions is usually out of control of the patient. And if there is any boundary‚Äôs crossed, the patient will often be referred out by the therapist.
